title.narrative: Waste to Clean Energy Fueling the future by Closing the Loops

description.narrative: Only 7% of rural Ugandans have access to electricity largely used for lighting as most cook on 3-stone fires using firewood. A 2018 GIZ report on creating evidence for market based approaches, reported the average fuelwood consumption for cooking in Imvepi Refugee Settlement as 7.5 kg of air-dried wood per refugee household daily for cooking and boiling in homes. A 2016 rapid assessment by UNHCR Uganda on Safe access to fuels and energy strategy revealed that 97 percent of refugees use firewood for cooking and yet have to walk a distance of 4-10 km to access firewood. This has resulted in refugees undercooking and skipping meals, while others sell some food rations to buy firewood, thus affecting their nutritional status. In Imvepi refugee settlement, 95% of the burden of collecting firewood is placed on women and girls. Moreover, the use of firewood for cooking exposes women and girls in particular to health risks that result from inhalation of poisonous gases. Shared use of natural resources was reported in the 2018 GIZ study as the major cause of conflict between refugees and hosts in Imvepi settlement. As a result, women and girls who collect nearly all the firewood, have experienced Sexual and Gender Based Violence through assaults, rape, attempted rape and defilement and physical altercation with the hosts and other refugees. These serious protection issues have affected the emotional wellbeing of refugees and further complicated their mental health needs.

Overall Objective
Improve accessibility by reducing distance for refugees and hosts in particular women to purchase quality and affordable clean energy solutions and/or obtain after sales/maintenance.
Short-term objectives - Increase number of households using renewable energy for cooking and lighting - Increase decent employment opportunities for refugees and host community - Regreen the ecosystem to reduce the impact of tree cutting for wood fuel in Imvepi refugee settlement

The consortium is proposing to work with 25% of the population of zone 3 of Imvepi refugee settlement; the zone has 2,959 households with a total population of 10,265 people of whom 52% are women. The project will work with 1,352 females (women and girls) and 598 (male and female) youth as primary users of both biogas and business opportunities. Men and the elderly will benefit from the project directly as users of gas. Women and children have 95% of the responsibility of collecting firewood and so will benefit directly. The project will support 83 entrepreneurs and 600 households set up and run enterprises on biogas and compost and grow and sell vegetables. 600 households will grow, maintain and manage tree nurseries which to be planted to regreen the area. The aged and child headed households will benefit as persons with special needs and will access biogas, horticulture and skills for employment. The project’s primary users will constitute hosts and refugees at a ratio of 30:70. With ambitions of expanding. The project will involve all community members in information sharing and communication to overcome barriers to social acceptance.

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Thematic Indicators
Number of people supported to improve and/or develop their entrepreneurship prospects

description.narrative: Number of people (within the project's target beneficiary group) supported by Cordaid interventions designed to assist them to develop / improve their entrepreneurship (possibilities)

title.narrative: Number of jobs created

description.narrative: Number of new jobs created by MSMEs, comparing before and after Cordaid's intervention (from baseline to Endline), counting only new jobs (not net jobs)

title.narrative: Number of SMEs reached

description.narrative: Number of SMEs tht have been reached directly or indirectly through the programme's activities.

title.narrative: Number of people reached with employment interventions

description.narrative: Number of people (within the project's target beneficiary group) supported by Cordaid interventions to obtain decent employment A decent employment respects the fundamental rights of the human person as well as the rights of workers in terms of conditions of work safety and remuneration. .. respect for the physical and mental integrity of the worker in the exercise of his/her employment (in accordance finally with the ILO regulations for decent work) .

title.narrative: Employment & Entrepreneurship Corporate Indicators
Number of farmer enterprises and MSMEs with improved access to finance

description.narrative: Number of enterprises (farmer enterprises or MSMEs) who have access to finance, comparing before and after our intervention (from baseline to Endline). NB A farmer group = 1 enterprise not 25 farmers. An individual farmer could be 1 enterprise

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Project Specific Indicators
Mobile digester for biogas operational (Y/N)
Distribution system of compost to tree nurseries and farmers is in place (Y/N)
Number of local entrepreneurs selling biogas
Number of fruit and vegetable farmers using compost of the digester
Average daily production of compost by digester (ltr)
Number of local entrepreneurs who have established businesses selling manure
Number of local entrepreneurs who have established tree nurseries using compost from the digester
Number of entrepreneurs trained and supported to operate tree nurseries
% of biogas beneficiaries who report and improvement in their related to upper and lower respiratory issues.
% of biogas beneficiaries who have an improved nutritional status
% of women and girls who report a decrease in SGBV instances
Number of households who have replaced their daily household energy demands (cooking and lighting) with biogas.
Number of households with access to a sufficient and continuous supply of biogas for daily use
Number of small businesses created (total)
Number of entrepreneurs trained and supported to sell biogas
Number of entrepreneurs trained and supported to deliver and sell compost
Number of fruit and vegetable farmers trained to use compost effectively
Number of entrepreneurs who accessed micro-credits to set up their businesses
Number of people provided with job skills training
